titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker Houston Rap Collection
Beste and Lance Scott Walker Houston Rap Collection
titlestmt.author: Stacey Lavender

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was encoded in EAD by Archon 3.21 from an SQL database source on October 14th, 2016.

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker Houston Rap Collection 1986/2014

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.unittitle: Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker Houston Rap Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: This collection consists of materials related to the creation and production of the book Houston Rap, by photographer Peter Beste and writer Lance Scott Walker. These materials include digital photos taken by Beste, audio recordings and transcripts of interviews conducted by Walker, photo prints from the editing process of the book, exhibit prints of photos from the book, photo contact sheets, and dummy copies of the book.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information:
bioghist.p: Peter Beste is a documentary photographer originally from Houston and now based in New Mexico and New York City. In the early 2000s, he spent six years working on his book True Norwegian Black Metal, for which he photographed several Norwegian black metal bands. After that project, he brought this documentary approach back to his hometown to explore the development of Houston hip hop.

Houston Rap, published in 2013 by Sinecure Press, is the joint creation of Beste and Lance Scott Walker. The product of nearly a decade of work, it documents Houston’s hip hop community, particularly in the Third Ward, Fifth Ward, and South Park neighborhoods. Comprised of photographs by Beste interspersed with excerpts from interviews conducted by Walker, the book features a wide swath of rappers, producers, and other members of Houston’s hip hop community. The rappers run the gamut from the very famous, like Bun B and Geto Boys, to the virtually unknown. The photographs often show the subjects in unguarded personal moments, revealing a world very unlike what the public sees on album covers and promotional materials. The interviews provide further insight into the communities and stories described in the artists’ lyrics.

Lance Scott Walker is a journalist, and native Texan, who has written for many publications, including the Houston Chronicle, Houston Press, USA Today, and RollingStone.com. Extended versions of the oral histories conducted by Walker for Houston Rap can be found in its companion, Houston Rap Tapes.

controlaccess.head: Access Terms
controlaccess.p: This Collection is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.
Reproduction decisions will be made by Special Collections staff on a case-by-case basis. Patrons are responsible for obtaining permission to publish from copyright holders.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker Houston Rap Collection. Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics or Technical Requirements:
phystech.p: Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact Julie Grob at jgrob@uh.edu for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials related to the creation and production of the book Houston Rap, by photographer Peter Beste and writer Lance Scott Walker. These materials include digital photos taken by Beste, audio recordings and transcripts of interviews conducted by Walker, photo prints from the editing process of the book, exhibit prints of photos from the book, photo contact sheets, and dummy copies of the book. The collection also contains a significant amount of material collected by the authors from various Houston hip hop artists, including recorded music, t-shirts, towels, posters, promo cards, and other memorabilia. The collection is divided into four series: Digital Files, Houston Rap Production and Promotion, Hip Hop Promotional and Research Material, and Music and Video. An important note: many of the materials found within the Digital Files series contain subject matter that would fit into other series within this collection.

This series contains all of the digital materials received from Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker, including digital photos, video, and interview audio files. Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact Julie Grob at jgrob@uh.edu for more information.

This sub-series consists of nearly 25,000 files from a hard-drive belonging to Peter Beste. It includes thousands of documentary photographs, various versions of and promotional materials for the book Houston Rap, scans and photos of ephemera collected from Houston hip hop artists, and video and audio files. All of the materials in this sub-series are found within a top-level folder on the hard drive entitled “HOUSTON.” The sub-sub-series represent the second-level folders in the hierarchy, and the folders within each represent the third-level folders in the hierarchy. Sub-sub-series and folder titles are taken directly from the hard drive. Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact Julie Grob at jgrob@uh.edu for more information.

This sub-sub-series contains photographs, postcards, and audio files collected from Houston hip hop artists, photographs taken of materials from the Hip Hop collections at the University of Houston, and other Houston hip hop ephemera collected by Walker and Beste.

did.unittitle: Poor recordings from 5th ward with willie d in 2004

scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-series contains materials related to the production and promotion of the book Houston Rap.
This sub-sub-series contains videos taken of members of the Houston hip hop community, usually either as part of an interview or for short promotional videos for the book Houston Rap.

did.unittitle: Early Dope E + Kyu Boi vids 2005 BY Christopher Rosales
GANXSTA NIP PLAYS ME HIS NEW ALBUM AT THE CAR WASH

scopecontent.p: This series contains thousands of documentary photos taken by Peter Beste while working on the book Houston Rap.
This series contains thousands of documentary photos taken by Peter Beste while working on the book Houston Rap.

This sub-series contains audio files and/or transcripts of interviews conducted by Lance Scott Walker with members of Houston’s hip hop community from 2005 to 2013. Each folder in this sub-series corresponds to a person who was interviewed and items within each folder represent audio files and transcripts associated with that person. Folders are arranged alphabetically by name, and folder descriptions were taken directly from an inventory provided by Beste and Walker. Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact Julie Grob at jgrob@uh.edu for more information.

did.unittitle: Al-B a.k.a. Elite Albee (Royal Flush) Interview

scopecontent.p: Member of the pioneering Houston rap group Royal Flush, who first emerged as battle rappers at the legendary Rhinestone Wrangler nightclub and later went on to release two albums on Rap-A-Lot. Topics include the late rapper Pimp C and his seldom-discussed religious beliefs. telephone interview (May 2012) audio.
Brother of the late DJ Screw and member of the Screwed Up Click who started his career with Houston label Jam Down Records. interview (2010) transcript + audio; telephone interview (March 2012) audio

Lesser known member of the South Park Coalition from Missouri City. Interview focuses on South Park and the scene surrounding it in the late '80s and early '90s. telephone interview (Fall 2010) transcript + audio

Houston entrepreneur and record producer who owns and operates Bam’s Auto Detailing in South Park, a community hub often talked about in Houston rap songs. He is the brother of Screwed Up Click member Mike-D, a.k.a. Bosshog Corleone. telephone interview (April 2012) audio; telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Former member of Convicts and Geto Boys whose real success came as a solo artist in the mid-'90s. He was later involved in a criminal incident of arson involving a Rap-A-Lot Records location and was imprisoned for years, now free and making music again. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio
Strip club promoter who provided access to after hours spots. telephone interview (November 2011) transcript + audio
Rapper/producer who was an early member of the group Royal Flush and is still an active producer. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Port Arthur born and raised rapper who was one half of UGK along with the late Pimp C. One of the most popular rappers in Houston. interview (2006) transcript + audio interview by Peter Beste (2012) audio + video

Important figure in Houston who has been an active MC and promoter in the rap community since the 1970s and is still part of the city's nightlife. He released one of the first Houston rap records with his single “Jack It Up” in 1984. telephone interview (Fall 2011) transcript + audio
Latino rapper best known for his 2007 album They Can’t Deport Us All. telephone interview (April 2012) audio
Younger member of the Screwed Up Click and also part of Slim Thug’s group Boss Hogg Outlawz. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Veteran rapper and notable voice in the South Park community in which her grandparents owned and operated the MLK Nite Club until Hurricane Ike destroyed it in 2008. telephone interview (Summer 2010) transcript + audio
Rapper/Producer who had at the time of the interview had already worked with UGK, Devin the Dude and Willie D before later relocating to Atlanta. telephone interview(2007) transcript
Veteran MC, b-boy, artist, and promoter active in Houston since the late 1980s. telephone interview (September 2008) transcript
Part of the newer wave of Houston rappers and one of very few artists from Baytown. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Houston DJ who started in the 1970s and pioneered the slowed down sound that DJ Screw would later adopt into his own genre. His mixtapes were the most popular in Houston's urban community throughout the 1980s. telephone interview (2007) transcript. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

The most popular Screwtape ever is June 27th, and it is Demo Sherman’s birthday tape. He is from Long Drive in South Park. telephone interview (October 2011) transcript + audio telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Owner and operator of Straight Profit Records. interview (2005) transcript
Owner and operator of Wreckshop Records, home of the late Fat Pat and the late Big Moe. telephone interview (2013) audio. interview (April 2014) transcript + audio
Producer and rapper for the Cloverland group Botany Boys. Conversations about DJ Screw and codeine cough syrup. telephone interview (Summer 2010) transcript + audio
Los Angeles transplant who is the promoter and manager for many artists in Houston. She worked closely with the late rapper Hawk. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio

Early friend of DJ Screw and still an active DJ all around Houston. Also runs a screen printing operation on the Southside. interview (2008) transcript + audio. telephone interview (2008) audio. telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Longtime Houston DJ and member of the radio collective Kracker Nuttz. Native of South Park. telephone interview (June 2012) audio
Port Arthur born and raised DJ, producer, and rapper who wrote the 1998 hit “25 Lighters,” and later became a Christian minister in Houston. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio

did.unittitle: DJ Domination a.k.a. DJ Domo Interview

scopecontent.p: Longtime DJ for Geto Boys, Scarface, and Devin the Dude. interview (2007) transcript

Lesser known member of the Screwed Up Click who now promotes a strip club on the South side of Houston near Missouri City. telephone interview (October 2011) transcript + audio. telephone interview (March 2012) audio

did.unittitle: Dope E. of The Terrorists Interview

scopecontent.p: Legendary Houston rapper and producer who is a founding member of the South Park Coalition and the early Rap-A-Lot artists The Terrorists. He has produced tracks for many Houston rappers over the years, and still makes records — now from his home base of Austin, TX. Also uses the alias Murdoq. telephone interview (Summer 2007) transcript. telephone interview (Fall 2010) transcript
Member of the group Guerilla Maab with Trae tha Truth and Z-Ro. interview by Peter Beste (2007) transcript
Female rapper who was a part of DJ Screw’s Screwed Up Click. telephone interview (March 2012) audio

Louisiana-born rapper whose career took off with the 1995 hit "Swangin' & Bangin'." Member of the Screwed Up Click and a big player in the squashing of the Northside/Southside war that plagued Houston throughout the 1990s when he reached out to collaborate with Northside rapper Slim Thug. E.S.G. stands for "Everyday Street Gangsta." interview (2005) transcript
President of Swishahouse Records. interview (2006) transcript
One of a newer wave of Houston. telephone interview (December 2012) audio

DJ and producer from the group Street Military. Interviewed along with longtime collaborator Mr. Baldhead, who appeared in the Vice documentary "Screwed In Houston" in 2007. telephone interview (April 2012) audio

Rapper and radio host who is a powerful voice in the Houston community. Member of the South Park Coalition and the group The 144 ELiTE along with K-Rino, Dope E and Ashlei Mayadia. Hosts the radio program Friday Eve along with Optimo Ram. telephone interview (October 2010) transcript + audio. telephone interview (November 2011) transcript + audio. telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Fifth Ward developer and community planner. telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Rapper and member of the Screwed Up Click who is the only living member of the original Dead End Alliance (DJ Screw, Fat Pat, Hawk). telephone interview (2007) transcript
Original member of the group Street Military. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio
Early member of the South Park Coalition and unofficial member of Street Military interviewed soon after being released from prison. telephone interview (May 2012) transcript + audio

did.unittitle: K-Otix (Micah Henderson and Damien Randle) Interview

scopecontent.p: Damien Randle and Micah Nickerson of the group K-Otix (which also featured The ARE) on writing the “George Bush Doesn't Care About Black People” song. telephone interview (Summer 2008) transcript

One of the earliest rappers in Houston and founder of the South Park Coalition. Member of the groups C.O.D. (with Dope E) and The 144 ELiTE. One of Houston’s most prolific rappers. interview (2006) transcript + audio. interview (October 2010) transcript + audio
Southside rapper who gave us a tour around South Acres. interview (2007) transcript
Member of South Park Coalition who was close to DJ Screw. One of our first tour guides into the Houston communities. interview (2007) transcript

Pioneering member of the Screwed Up Click from Herschelwood who came up alongside Fat Pat. His biggest hit is "Southside," based on a dance that was one of many created by him and Fat Pat. interview (Spring 2006) transcript
Mixtape DJ who guested with Screw and is one of the only DJs still using Screw’s method of making tapes. telephone interview (Fall 2010) transcript + audio. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Rapper, producer and businessman from South Park's Dead End best known for his 1999 hit "Wanna Be A Baller." Had a well-publicized beef with the rapper Scarface, who first recorded with Troy as DJ Akshen and would later be accused by Troy of snitching for the government. Now runs a strip club on the East Side. telephone interview (September 2010) transcript + audio telephone interview (May 2012) audio
Member of the Screwed Up Click and brother of Macc Grace a.k.a. Dat Boy Grace. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio
Writer, promoter and radio host with deep Houston roots now based in Austin. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

New York-born longtime Fifth Ward denizen responsible for bringing a lot of Houston talent to the scene by booking their first shows for them. His interviews form a big part of both books. telephone interview (February 2010) transcript + audio. telephone interview (December 2011) transcript + audio
Host of numerous live radio broadcasts around Houston. Has been a fixture in the clubs since arriving in Houston in the early '90s. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio

Best known as the wife of the late rapper Hawk, Meshah was a presence in the Third Ward community before his death and even more so after his murder in 2006. She is the mother of his two young sons. This conversation talks about Third Ward history. telephone interview (December 2011) transcript + audio. telephone interview (March 2012) audio

Member of the Screwed Up Click and the group Southside Playaz and close friend of the late Fat Pat and the late DJ Screw. Frequent collaborator of Z-Ro's. Brother of Bamino, a.k.a. BAM. Interviews conducted right after his release from prison for a piece by Walker for the Houston Chronicle. telephone interview (April 2012) audio. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Founder and owner of Beltway 8 Records who started his label in Prairie View, Texas even though its focus was in Houston. He was able to turn the label into a profitable venture before exiting the business in 2010, right at the time of this interview, to making cooking (specifically barbecue) a profession. telephone interview (January 2010) transcript + audio
Muslim minister in Houston and longtime advisor to many of the people featured in Houston Rap and Houston Rap Tapes. telephone interview (December 2011) transcript + audio
Southside car customizer who has operated a car wash in South Park for years. telephone interview (Spring 2010) transcript + audio

Original member of the South Park Coalition. Longtime collaborator of K-Rino with a solo career appearances on most all SPC-related releases. telephone interview (2008) transcript telephone interview (2010) transcript + audio
Radio host who has emerged in the last five years and filled a big void with virtually around the clock Houston music and talk on the radio. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio
Longtime program director at Texas Southern University’s KTSU, where the early Houston rap radio show Kidz Jamm debuted in the early 1980s. telephone interview (June 2012) audio

Wide-ranging interview with the white rapper who is rarely referred to as such. Topics include grills, blood diamonds, and performing for troops in war zones. telephone interview (January 2012) transcript + audio
Chicago-born rapper who moved to South Park as a teenager and joined the Screwed Up Click. Later signed to Bigtyme Recordz. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio

Member of the group often to referred to as the younger brothers of the late rapper Hawk, who was shot and killed in 2006. This interview talks about the night of the murder. interview (May 2007) transcript + audio
Former KPFT radio host who has been a punk/rap scene fixture in Houston since the late 1980s. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

The first Houston rapper signed to a major label, Raheem was an original member of Ghetto Boys before launching his solo career with A&M Records. Later signed to Rap-A-Lot. telephone interview (2008) transcript

Also known as DJ Troy Ski, he arrived in the city from Pittsburgh in the early 1980s and was a part of the early crews in the city before moving into the business side of things. Now involved in the sports industry. telephone interview (2012) audio

Original DJ/producer for Ghetto Boys/Geto Boys, who left the group in 1991 during the production of their platinum breakthrough album We Can't Be Stopped. telephone interview (Summer 2008) transcript + audio
South Park Coalition rapper who has been a lifelong friend of the rapper K-Rino. telephone interview (2010) transcript + audio
Founding member of Royal Flush and one of Houston's early battle rappers. He now hosts a radio show in Dallas under the name Coco Budda. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Early Northside rapper who went to high school with Willie D at Forest Brook and later became known as a formidable battle rapper and joined the group Royal Flush. telephone interview (May 2012) audio
Owner and operator of Bigtyme Recordz, the first label to sign UGK, which has operated out of King’s Flea Market in South Park for over two decades. telephone interview (Fall 2011) transcript + audio

Austin-based producer who created the beat for the breakthrough Houston hit “Still Tippin’,” which touched off the mainstream explosion Houston experienced in 2005. telephone interview (Spring 2007) transcript

Underground rapper who leads the group known as H.I.S.D. (Hueston Independent Spit District), some of whom are Houston area teachers. Also a member of the group The Hue. telephone interview (March 2012) audio

One of DJ Screw's oldest friends and a Smithville, TX native (DJ Screw's hometown). Important interview subject in Houston Rap and Houston Rap Tapes. telephone interview (Winter 2008/2009) transcript + audio. telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Rapper and promoter from Houston's Third Ward. telephone interview (Summer 2011) transcript + audio
Northside rapper who was featured on the breakthrough track "Still Tippin'" along with Mike Jones and Paul Wall. telephone interview (Spring 2013) transcript + audio

Current incarnation of the group that originally featured Fat Pat, Mike-D and Mr. 3-2. Upon Fat Pat's death, his place in the group was taken by Clay Doe. Interview with Mike-D, Mr. 3-2, and Clay Doe conducted on the street outside of the original Screwed Up Records & Tapes. interview (2006) transcript

Legendary Houston DJ who helped rap music break through to the big clubs and started the nation's first rap record pool. Talks about being arrested for playing rap music in Houston nightclubs. telephone interview (May 2012) audio

Swishahouse producer who started as an intern and worked his way up to having his own label under the Swishahouse umbrella. He was one of the architects of the 2005 Houston juggernaut. interview (2006) transcript

Producer from the group K-Otix who has since worked with stars as big as LL Cool J, Lone Catalysts, and Phife from A Tribe Called Quest. telephone interview (2007) transcript telephone interview (May 2012) audio
Car customizer who grew up in Houston’s Third Ward and now owns a shop in Austin. telephone interview (October 2011) transcript + audio
Former pimp and member of the South Park Coaltion who has converted over to Christianity and now writes books. telephone interview (2007) transcript

Part of the second wave of rappers to become part of the Screwed Up Click and longtime collaborator of Z-Ro’s. Member of the groups S.L.A.B., Guerilla Maab, and ABN. telephone interview (March 2012) audio
Former Rice University DJ whose Friday night radio program Bass 9-1-7 Zone was pioneering in the Houston radio market. telephone interview (2012) audio

One of the first Houston rappers. Battle rapper who turned solo artist and then joined Geto Boys, with a parallel solo career and short stint as a professional boxer, following in the footsteps of his uncle Melvin Dennis. interview 2007 transcript. telephone interview (April 2010) transcript + audio. telephone interview (December 2011) transcript + audio. telephone interview (May 2012) audio
Lesser-known member of the Screwed Up Click who tells a story of growing up with a mother addicted to crack and how he turned his and her lives around. telephone interview (2008) transcript

One of the most widely respected and prolific artists in Houston, and one of the biggest draws at Houston's massive rap clubs. Founding member of the groups Guerilla Maab and ABN and a member of the Screwed Up Click. interview (September 2011) transcript + audio + video

This series contains photo prints, contact sheets, proofs, and mock-ups used in the production of the book Houston Rap, along with exhibit prints, stickers, publications, and promo cards used to promote the book and its authors. The series is divided into three sub-series: Photo Prints and Contact Sheets, Book Mock-Ups and Proofs, and Houston Rap Promotional Materials and Publications. Additional materials relating to the production and promotion of Houston Rap can be found in the Digital Files series.

Hip Hop Promotional and Research Material

scopecontent.p: This series contains T-shirts, posters, promo cards, photographs, correspondence, publications, and memorabilia collected by Peter Beste and Lance Scott Walker from hip hop artists and other members of the hip hop community in Houston during their work on the book Houston Rap. It is divided into six sub-series: T-shirts and Towels; Posters, Poster Flats, and Promo Cards; Photographs; Correspondence; Memorabilia; and Publications. Scans and photos of additional materials collected by Beste and Walker from members of Houston’s hip hop community can be found in the Digital Files series.

scopecontent.p: This series contains audio and video recordings collected by Beste and Walker during their work on the book Houston Rap. It also contains a small number of handwritten lyrics. This series is divided into four subseries: Handwritten lyrics, Compact discs, Audiocassettes, and 45 rpm records. In addition to the items listed below, 22 DVDs, 4 VHS tapes, 180 compact discs, 17 audiocassettes, and 19 vinyl records were removed for cataloguing

did.unittitle: Handwritten lyrics by DJ DMD for “25 Lighters”
Handwritten lyrics by Justice Allah for “F.T.P” and “Love”
8 compact discs featuring various hip hop artists
